content.statement: Cash Flow is the net amount of cash moving into and out of a business or project over a specific time period, representing actual money transfers rather than accounting profits.
content.intuition: Cash flow is about actual money movements, not accounting profits. A profitable company on paper can go bankrupt if it runs out of cash. 'Cash is King' in finance.
key_insights: Cash flows are actual money movements, not accrual accounting figures
Operating cash flow excludes financing and investing activities
Free cash flow is cash available after necessary capital expenditures
Positive NPV projects must have positive expected cash flows

components.operating_cash_flow: Cash from core business operations (OCF = EBIT + Depreciation - Taxes - ΔWorking Capital)
components.cash_inflows: Revenue collections, asset sales, financing receipts
components.cash_outflows: Operating expenses, CAPEX, debt payments, dividends

adjustments: Subtract changes in working capital (AR, Inventory, AP)
Subtract capital expenditures for maintenance and growth
Adjust for tax effects on a cash basis

mathematical_representations.python:
def cash_flow(revenue, costs, taxes, delta_wc, capex):
    return revenue - costs - taxes - delta_wc - capex

Revenue_t.description: Cash collected from sales in period t

Costs_t.description: Cash operating expenses in period t

Taxes_t.description: Cash taxes paid in period t

delta_WC.description: Change in working capital (increase is cash outflow)

sources.title: Valuation: Measuring and Managing the Value of Companies

learning_objectives: Distinguish cash flows from accounting profits
Calculate free cash flow from financial statements
common_errors: Including financing costs in FCF (should exclude)
practice_problems: Company has $1M profit, $200K depreciation, $100K increase in AR, $50K decrease in AP. Calculate operating cash flow.
Project generates $500K revenue, $300K costs, $50K taxes yearly. Initial investment $800K, salvage value $100K after 5 years. Calculate annual FCF.
